Secretary Colin Powell is quite right that entitlement programs are where the real money is. But just one month after Pop Idol premiered in 2001, the tabloid Sunday People zeroed in on Simon Cowell under the headline WOMEN FANS FALL FOR MR. NASTY. The record boss is being chased by besotted women wanting to get to know him better-despite his sarcastic comments and cutting remarks to young wannabes on the hit ITV talent show. As his public profile rose, Simon Cowell took action to manage his image. Over 40 when Pop Idol began, Simon Cowell had had a handful of semipublic romances with singers and model types.
